Keyword: Artificial Intelligence: Computer Science-Based Breakdown
Machine Learning
Supervised Learning: Learning from labeled data to make predictions or classify data.
Linear Regression: Predicting a continuous output based on linear relationships.
Logistic Regression: Classification algorithm for binary or multiclass problems.
Support Vector Machines (SVMs): Finding the optimal hyperplane for classification.
Decision Trees: Tree-based models for decision-making and classification.
Random Forests: An ensemble of decision trees to improve accuracy.
Neural Networks: Computational models inspired by the human brain.
Backpropagation: A method for training neural networks by adjusting weights.
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs): Specialized neural networks for image recognition.
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs): Neural networks for sequential data.
Unsupervised Learning: Finding patterns in data without labeled responses.
K-Means Clustering: Partitioning data into k clusters based on similarity.
Hierarchical Clustering: Building nested clusters in a hierarchical manner.
Principal Component Analysis (PCA): Reducing dimensionality of data.
Autoencoders: Neural networks for learning efficient codings of input data.
Reinforcement Learning: Learning optimal actions through trial and error.
Q-Learning: A value-based method for finding the best action to take.
Deep Q-Networks (DQN): Combining Q-learning with deep learning.
Policy Gradients: Directly optimizing the policy to select actions.
Neural Networks and Deep Learning
Feedforward Neural Networks (FNNs): Networks with no cycles, moving data forward.
Activation Functions: Functions like ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh used in neurons.
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs): Networks with convolutional layers for spatial data.
Pooling Layers: Downsampling layers to reduce dimensionality.
Transfer Learning: Using pre-trained models for new tasks.
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs): Networks with cycles for sequential data.
Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM): Specialized RNNs for capturing long-term dependencies.
Gated Recurrent Units (GRUs): A simpler alternative to LSTMs.
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs): Two networks (generator and discriminator) competing against each other.
StyleGAN: GAN for generating high-quality images.
Transformers: Models using self-attention mechanisms for NLP and other tasks.
BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers): Pre-trained model for various NLP tasks.
GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer): Model for generating human-like text.
Natural Language Processing (NLP)
Tokenization: Breaking text into individual words or subwords.
Named Entity Recognition (NER): Identifying and classifying entities in text.
SpaCy: An open-source NLP library for NER and other tasks.
Sentiment Analysis: Determining the emotional tone of text.
VADER: A lexicon and rule-based sentiment analysis tool.
Machine Translation: Automatically translating text from one language to another.
seq2seq Models: Sequence-to-sequence models for translation.
Text Generation: Creating human-like text based on input data.
GPT-3: A powerful language model for text generation.
Computer Vision
Image Classification: Categorizing images into predefined classes.
ResNet: A deep residual network for image recognition.
Object Detection: Identifying and localizing objects within images.
YOLO (You Only Look Once): A real-time object detection system.
Image Segmentation: Partitioning images into segments for analysis.
U-Net: A neural network architecture for biomedical image segmentation.
Image Generation: Creating new images from scratch.
DCGAN (Deep Convolutional GAN): A GAN for generating realistic images.
Robotics and Autonomous Systems
Path Planning: Finding a path from a start to a goal position.
A Algorithm:* A popular pathfinding and graph traversal algorithm.
Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM): Building a map while tracking the robot's location.
ORB-SLAM: A feature-based SLAM system for monocular, stereo, and RGB-D cameras.
Robot Perception: Understanding the environment through sensors.
LIDAR: Light Detection and Ranging for mapping and navigation.
Control Systems: Algorithms for controlling robotic movements.
PID Controller: A control loop mechanism for maintaining a desired output.
Expert Systems and Decision Making
Rule-Based Systems: Systems using predefined rules to make decisions.
Drools: A business rule management system.
Fuzzy Logic: Handling reasoning that is approximate rather than fixed.
Fuzzy Control Systems: Controllers using fuzzy logic for decision making.
Bayesian Networks: Probabilistic graphical models for decision making.
Junction Tree Algorithm: An algorithm for exact inference in Bayesian networks.
Reinforcement Learning
Markov Decision Processes (MDPs): Mathematical models for decision making.
Value Iteration: Computing the optimal policy by iterating on value functions.
Policy Iteration: Iterating on policy improvement and evaluation.
Actor-Critic Methods: Combining value-based and policy-based approaches.
Data Science and Big Data
Data Preprocessing: Cleaning and transforming raw data for analysis.
Pandas: A data manipulation library for Python.
Data Visualization: Creating visual representations of data.
Matplotlib: A plotting library for Python.
Big Data Technologies: Handling large-scale data processing.
Hadoop: A framework for distributed storage and processing of big data.
Spark: A unified analytics engine for big data processing.
Cognitive Computing
Speech Recognition: Converting spoken language into text.
CMU Sphinx: An open-source speech recognition system.
Text-to-Speech (TTS): Generating spoken language from text.
Google TTS: A text-to-speech service.
Cognitive Models: Simulating human thought processes in a computer model.
ACT-R (Adaptive Control of Thought-Rational): A cognitive architecture for simulating human cognition.
Ethical and Social Implications
Bias and Fairness: Ensuring AI systems do not perpetuate biases.
Fairness Indicators: Tools to evaluate the fairness of machine learning models.
Privacy: Protecting sensitive information in AI systems.
Differential Privacy: Techniques to ensure individual data privacy.
AI Ethics: Guidelines for the responsible use of AI.
Ethical AI Frameworks: Standards and principles for ethical AI development.
